s.text: In a way, this is not a dodge.
Let's wait and see if he does it!
I asked him why other countries should risk their soldiers' lives if the United States wouldn't, and he replied, "I didn't say 'other nations,' I said the United Nations."

As I understand it, an exit strategy is a sort of poor man's Powell Doctrine.
So this is a great way to sound tough and sophisticated without actually committing yourself.
Go in full force from the beginning rather than escalate yourself into a quagmire.

They will be familiar from intervention disputes dating back at least to Vietnam, but they are especially useful for the summer-squall-style military actions of today, in which we all agree to be frenzied about the occupation of Kuwait or a drug-smuggling dictator in Panama or warlords in Somalia or genocide in Bosnia on the strict understanding that we will be allowed to forget all about these matters and places in six months, max.

When an answer moves beyond difficult to completely impossible, it becomes easy once again.
In a former life I used to interrogate politicians on television, and in six years there was never a subject on which they were unable to come up with an easy answer.
What is an easy answer?
"There are no easy answers" is itself an easy answer--if you can get away with it.
Here are half a dozen consumer-tested easy answers on issues like Kosovo:
An easy answer, for a politician, is one that assures you will never be proved wrong.
Easy Answers
Easy answers to the rescue!
Not necessarily a correct answer--or honest or heartfelt or logically coherent--but easy.

It is often said that there are no easy answers, but in fact there are.
Watch for these easy answers on the TV talk shows and in the newspaper.
